justification: The AUDIT was chosen to assess alcohol dependence based on its brief assessment ease and reliability for primary care and research settings.
The BDS was chosen to measure the level of binge drinking among the sample, capturing the number of drinks consumed in a short period.
The BIS-11 was validated for good psychometric properties in both research and clinical environments for quantifying impulsivity.
The IGT was used to assess how much participants preferred disadvantageous choices over advantageous ones, reflecting their risky decision-making tendencies.
Participants rated statements on a 9-point Likert scale to measure their desire for alcohol at the time of assessment.
The AAT required participants to move a hand image towards or away from alcohol-related pictures, measuring their subconscious craving for alcohol.
